definition: Qiu Jin (1875-1907), famous female martyr of the anti-Qing revolution, the subject of several books and films
autumn/fall/harvest time
surname Qiu
brilliancy (of gems)

sentences.english: Having no confession is a focus of Qiu Jins unjust case before her death.
sentences.chinese: 秋瑾死前沒有供詞是秋瑾冤案的一個焦點。

sentences.english: Having no confession is a focus of Qiu Jins unjust case before her death.
sentences.chinese: 秋瑾死前沒有供詞是秋瑾冤案的一個焦點。

sentences.english: Lu Xun's pursuit of the transmutation of human nature, his desire to become Qiu Jin Ah Q.
sentences.chinese: 魯迅追求的是人性的嬗變，他渴望的是阿Q變成秋瑾。

sentences.english: Qiu Jin, the heroine of Jianhu Lake, is a lady of great love.
sentences.chinese: 秋瑾自號鑑湖女俠，她是個充滿愛心的人。

definition: Tan Sitong (1865-1898), Qing writer and politician, one of the Six Gentlemen Martyrs 戊戌六君子 of the unsuccessful reform movement of 1898
Chen Tianhua (1875-1905), anti-Qing revolutionary from Hunan, drowned himself in Japan in 1905
Song Jiaoren (1882-1913), politician of the revolutionary party involved in the 1911 Xinhai revolution, murdered in Shanghai in 1913
Li Dazhao (1889-1927), early Chinese Marxist and founding member of the communist party
Chen Duxiu (1879-1942), co-founder of the Chinese Communist Party in 1921
anti-Qing revolutionary party set up in 1904 under Cai Yuanpei 蔡元培/same as 復古會|复古会
Cai Yuanpei (1868-1940), liberal educationalist, studied in Germany, president of Peking University 1917-19, minister of education for Guomindang
Zhang Taiyan (1869-1936), scholar, journalist, revolutionary and leading intellectual around the time of the Xinhai revolution

the Six Gentlemen Martyrs of the failed reform movement of 1898, executed in its aftermath, namely: Tan Sitong 譚嗣同|谭嗣同[Tan2 Si4 tong2], Lin Xu 林旭[Lin2 Xu4], Yang Shenxiu 楊深秀|杨深秀[Yang2 Shen1 xiu4], Liu Guangdi 劉光第|刘光第[Liu2 Guang1 di4], Kang Guangren 康廣仁|康广仁[Kang1 Guang3 ren2] and Yang Rui 楊銳|杨锐[Yang2 Rui4]
Cai E (1882-1916), originator of the National protection army of 1915
Huang Xing (1874-1916), revolutionary politician, close collaborator of Sun Yat-sen, prominent in the 1911 Xinhai Revolution 辛亥革命[Xin1 hai4 Ge2 ming4], murdered in Shanghai in 1916
Yang Kaihui (1901-1930), Mao Zedong's second wife
Hu Shi (1891-1962), original proponent of writing in colloquial Chinese 白話文|白话文[bai2 hua4 wen2]
Zhang Shizhao (1881-1973), revolutionary journalist in Shanghai, then established writer
Yu Dafu (1896-1945), poet and novelist
Dr Sun Yat-sen (1866-1925), first president of the Republic of China and co-founder of the Guomintang 國民黨|国民党/same as 孫逸仙|孙逸仙
